newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine president says Cavallo's graft charges lies.
newsitem.headline: Argentine president says Cavallo's graft charges lies.

text.p: Argentine President Carlos Menem on Wednesday dismissed as lies charges by former Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo that two cabinet ministers covered up corruption and manipulated judges.
"Of course that's a lie," he told foreign correspondents.

Cavallo, who first denounced "mafias" in ruling Peronist Party circles a year ago, on Tuesday said Interior Minister Carlos Corach had tried to remove a judge from investigating a gold-export fraud case and replace him with another magistrate "who failed to find any crime committed by gold exporters."
Both Corach and Justice Minister Elias Jassan were manipulating judges and state prosecutors, alleged Cavallo, the architect of Argentina's economic reform plan.

But Menem, who last July sacked his "superminister" after one too many brawls over his austerity policies, told reporters: "Let's not get confused, for God's sake. Cavallo is no longer in the government. He is now in the opposition."
"There are no mafias in the government," Menem said.

Cavallo, who last week announced he will run for Congress in 1997, but not for Menem's Peronist Party, said the two ministers had made self-incriminating comments but he had no tape recordings or documentation on the alleged conversations.

"It's my word against those of the two ministers," Cavallo said at a dinner at New York University, where he is teaching economics. "It's a question of credibility -- do the people believe in what I say or in what they say?"

Local Argentine bonds fell early on Wednesday on worries about the political consequences of the attacks. But Menem brushed aside those concerns, saying, "Markets fell everywhere in the world. I don't think it is because of Cavallo."
In a statement issued on Tuesday, Corach rejected the charges, calling them "totally irresponsible and reflecting (Cavallo's) state of emotional imbalance." He also said he would take legal action.
Federal Judge Adolfo Bagnasco challenged Cavallo to come forth with a napkin on which he claims Corach once wrote the names of several judges and state prosecutors and bragged, "These do as I say."
"All else is heresay, resembling more a Mexican soap opera than any other thing," the judge said.

Menem also dismissed as mere electioneering charges by another former aide, former Interior Minister Gustavo Beliz, who said this week that many Argentines saw Menem "almost" as the head of alleged mafias infiltrating the government.
"These two ministers (Cavallo and Beliz) are referring to totally non-existent mafias," said Menem, who did not rule out legal action against Beliz.
